title: 106_s1514
content: The Act is titled the "International Anti-Corruption Act of 1999" and includes limitations on foreign assistance. The President must submit a certification and report to the appropriate committees by March 1 each year regarding countries that received foreign assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The report evaluates economic progress based on indicators like economic reform, private ownership, protection of intellectual property rights, and elimination of corrupt trade practices. The certification evaluates countries based on economic indicators like private ownership, protection of intellectual property rights, and elimination of corrupt trade practices. It determines if a country is conducive, not conducive, or hostile to United States business. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 prohibits funds for countries hostile to US business. The Secretary of the Treasury must oppose loans to such countries in multilateral development banks. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 prohibits funds for countries hostile to US business. The limitations on countries certified as not conducive to United States business apply until significant progress is made in implementing economic indicators. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 prohibits funds for countries not conducive to US business unless significant progress is made in implementing economic indicators. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 restricts funds for countries not supporting US business unless economic progress is achieved. The Secretary of the Treasury must direct US representatives in multilateral development banks to vote against funding for countries failing to meet certification requirements. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 restricts funds for countries not conducive to US business until they show economic progress. Exceptions can be made for national security interests. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 restricts funds for countries not conducive to US business until they show economic progress. Exceptions can be made for national security interests, including assistance for urgent humanitarian needs, democratic political reform, private sector development, and free market economic systems. The Secretary of Commerce will provide a toll-free number for reporting on the progress of countries receiving foreign assistance in implementing economic indicators. Information from this reporting will be included in the required report. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The term "multilateral development bank" includes specific international banks.
